content.html: How about using IGN_DTOR and IGN_RTOD instead of defining new ones? See here

content.html: This is not needed for this PR, can we remove it for now and add it when it is needed?

content.raw: This works for arbitrary line, circle intersections. I have updated the documentation.
content.html: This works for arbitrary line, circle intersections. I have updated the documentation.

content.raw:
Could you add an example test where `_pc` is not on the line and the function returns true?

If this id 3D, are we talking about a sphere instead of a circle?
content.html:
Could you add an example test where _pc is not on the line and the function returns true?

If this id 3D, are we talking about a sphere instead of a circle?

content.raw:
sure. 

I am doing the intersection between the line's 2d projection and the circle, so it is in 2d only.
content.html:
sure.

I am doing the intersection between the line's 2d projection and the circle, so it is in 2d only.

content.raw: Since this is 2D, could we use `Line2`? All your test examples have Z == 0.
content.html: Since this is 2D, could we use Line2? All your test examples have Z == 0.

content.raw: This function is used on the positions of the agent in gameState. These are in 3D, so there is no benefit to using Line2D
content.html: This function is used on the positions of the agent in gameState. These are in 3D, so there is no benefit to using Line2D

content.raw: Makes sense. Could you add a test case with a Line3 where Z != 0? It can be something simple like `Line3(-999, -999, -999, 999, 999, 999)`
content.html: Makes sense. Could you add a test case with a Line3 where Z != 0? It can be something simple like Line3(-999, -999, -999, 999, 999, 999)

content.raw:
Can't we just use [Plane::Side](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/94aa797a1bfeb5e3c44072a12ddc1475c49af322/src/Plane_TEST.cc#Plane_TEST.cc-83) instead? If you need a `bool`, then something like:

~~~
return _plane.Side(_pt) == Planed::POSITIVE_SIDE;
~~~
content.html:
Can't we just use Plane::Side instead? If you need a bool, then something like:

return _plane.Side(_pt) == Planed::POSITIVE_SIDE;

content.raw: Could you document better what this value is?
content.html: Could you document better what this value is?

content.raw:
Where did these values come from?

It's usually nice to check against values we know how to derive using a different logic from the one inside the function.
content.html:
Where did these values come from?

It's usually nice to check against values we know how to derive using a different logic from the one inside the function.

content.raw: I calculated these using an online calculator for the intersection between plane and line
content.html: I calculated these using an online calculator for the intersection between plane and line

content.raw: I see. Maybe you can add a comment with a link to the calculator so we have a reference?
content.html: I see. Maybe you can add a comment with a link to the calculator so we have a reference?

content.raw:
Wouldn't it be better to call this `Spherical` instead of `Polar`? Wikipedia tells me [polar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_coordinate_system) is 2D while [spherical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_coordinate_system) is 3d.

Also it would be good to describe in the documentation what the vector elements mean (radius, polar angle, azimuthal angle)
content.html:
Wouldn't it be better to call this Spherical instead of Polar? Wikipedia tells me polar is 2D while spherical is 3d.

Also it would be good to describe in the documentation what the vector elements mean (radius, polar angle, azimuthal angle)
